channel.name: Can I access the `picklesProver` function publicly in SmartContract?

messages.content:
When compiling a SmartContract using the `.compile()` method, the keys: `_methodMetadata`, `_verificationKey`, and `_provers` are newly created in the class. Inside `_provers`, there's an array pointing to an asynchronous function:

```
[ [AsyncFunction: picklesProver] ]
```

The content of this function is:
```
async function picklesProver(publicInput, previousProofs) {
    return prettifyStacktracePromise(withThreadPool(() => prover(publicInput, previousProofs)));
}
```

As I understand it, this reference is required to execute the later `.prove()` function. From my tests, this function shouldn't retrieve any user-specific data. Instead, these are inserted through the call.

I am looking for a way to bypass the compilation process by loading the pre-made verification key locally into the program. This seems to work to some extent, but there always has to be a reference to this `provers[0]` function.

Storing and reusing the VerificationKey would bring significant user-friendliness. And save more than 60 seconds per transaction. Can I access this function `picklesProver(publicInput, previousProofs)` publicly? Or is there another intended way to optimize this?

I appreciate any advice.

verification key and provers are two separate things, you can save the verification key already today - its just a long string that doesnt require any additional serialisation efforts. You get it as a return from compile()

Provers on the other hand are programatically constructed based on the circuit thats being proven, these are created by a lenghty compilation. Afaik there’s work being done to serialize the already compiled provers, so that you dont have to recompile every time you want to use provers to prove / create a proof.

Note: i am unsure if creating the provers or the verification key is the time expensive part
Depending on if you use SmartContract or ZkProgram, you can use mock proofs instead of running provers to create real proofs

I appreciate your response. It seems that there might have been a slight misunderstanding in my previous question, as your answer provided general keywords. This topic holds significant importance for me, and I am seeking a comprehensive clarification. To simplify the matter:

How can I use a previously saved verification key instead of creating a new one every i run the code?

I hope this clarifies it.

The only thing you can do with a previously persisted verification key is verify proofs created by the same circuit. You can import { verify } from ‘snarkyjs’ and pass your verification key and proof to it
Also you can pass the verification key as a private input to a zkapp
Going back to my original answer to this, verification key isnt a prover. You can’t use a verification key to compute a proof, only to verify it.

@maht0rz, all of my messages are related.

I will rephrase my last message as a new question. You can consider that question closed for you. Your responses are not providing the assistance I need.

The answer is no: you can’t do it today as i’ve explained in my original message. 

When you call your smart contract method it issues account updates, these need to be authorized by e.g. a proof.

Therefore you call .prove() to call a prover behind the scenes, which computes proofs for all associated account updates. 

Having the verification key of your circuit is not useful at all in this stage. 

Once your proven account updates arrive at the L1, the block producer takes the verification key and uses it to verify the proofs created by the provers - which you cannot serialize at this point.
I’m sure @gregor or @Florian can answer this as well, confirming my understanding 🙌
alternatively, a deep dive into snarkyjs will also confirm what i’ve said ^^
@maht0rz, I kindly request that you maintain a professional tone and refrain from using offensive emojis.

He graciously responded to your question and provided a thorough explanation as to why achieving what you are attempting may not be feasible (yet). Instead of acknowledging his answer, you requested him to stop responding. **That** is offensive.

I'm sure that if you read it over again, it will become clearer to you

The answer provided by @maht0rz is correct in every aspect, as far as I know. It may not match your wishes, but that is a different thing, and in no way offensive. Also, please consider that this is a community effort. Just other community member such as @maht0rz graciously giving his time to help others  and answering questions.

Additionally here’s a link to the snarkyjs issue which explains it too:

https://github.com/o1-labs/snarkyjs/issues/87

Yes that’s correct. Compiling a smart contract gives you two artifacts: a verification key (can be serialised) and a prover (which can’t be serialised *yet*). If a user wants to interact with a deployed smart contract, they need to compile the original source code to retrieve the prover artifacts
